column7: #### This room is inactive, and only exists for archival purposes. Join some active rooms - here's the full list: https://www.freecodecamp.com/wiki/en/official-free-code-camp-chat-rooms/

It’s also nice because it provides us a way of having copyrighted music during events we do want to archive, like Camp Wide Meetings, Demo Days, etc.

@benmcmahon100 Yes, this is a great alternative to how we’d previously been doing it. I probably won’t do it myself because I’m on a resource-strapped mac book air, but I imagine many campers will be able to take advantage of this.
And the stream and the recording doesn't depend on each other so no multipack part BIDS on twitch anymore
It also spreads resource usage across two machines as opposed to one

You know the may moobot handles the songs
does it not?
I don’t understand what you mean. It looks at the outgoing audio, not your own audio.
that's the critical part
but can you stream and have it so you can't hear the music that is playing?
I know I've watched them
[![Twitch.png](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/TwitchTV/QW1J/thumb/Twitch.png)](https://files.gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/TwitchTV/QW1J/Twitch.png)
Even in playback, Twitch mutes sections that have copyrighted audio
Can you play music over the stream without listening to it yourself?
Yes
You know the way when you stream you can hear the music
We could play it back and screen record it. That would reduce the quality though
@QuincyLarson bare with me for one sec
@benmcmahon100 OK - then how do we get archived footage?
What I'm suggesting is don't export
Twitch is a really closed system. Their exporting mechanic is quite rigid.
the difficulty arises where when you stream you can hear the music correct?
OK - see if you can figure out a way to achieve both.
and both can be achieved

We need to determine whether it’s even worth archiving this footage. If 100 people ultimately view a clip, but you churned 100 viewers during your coding session because you didn’t have music, then you merely broke even.
I get that but last night was a prime example where you wanted both
2) We want to be able to export SOME content (not all of it - most of it is chaff) for archived viewing
1) We want music. It improves viewer retention
@benmcmahon100 let’s take a step back and discuss what our goal is here
Being able to request songs, and having good music, is a big part of the draw.
@QuincyLarson can you stream and play music but without listening to the music yourself?
@benmcmahon100 obviously, we want the stream to be able to hear Moobot
@benmcmahon100 I think the issue is the music won’t make it out to the stream.
The key is keeping rules simple enough that people can remember and follow them, even if it’s sub-optimal
Also can you chose what audio device plays audio on a per application basis

Here’s what I recommend we do: 
for normal coding sessions (not special programs) use the Moobot radio station.
for special coding sessions (pair programming hour, demo day, etc) just don’t play music.
If you switch from normal coding to special coding, stop and start the stream so it will create a new instance of the stream (without any music)
@QuincyLarson I think it can be done! It's a bit hackey but i think it can be done!
@jsonify @benmcmahon100 Yes, I don’t think it’s possible to stream music to the audience and also strip that music out of the stream for archiving without also losing the audio.
@jsonify I'm on it!
I'm in a meeting for another few hours, but if you're able to do it later, I would be interested in seeing it
yeah and I dont think OBS can isolate tracks
Ahh. When we stream to Twitch, it automatically combines the tracks
I 'll set it up on my machine now!
two hours of 720p video is fairly big!
I'd be interested in seeing it in action
the issue would be storage
actually now that i think about it recording software would have that much CPU/RAM overhead
Yeah I've seen it be done before where you'll capture system sounds + a mic and ignore everything else
And still keep the dialogue track?
the issue that I see is that a lot if not all the people who currently stream lack the computer power to run OBS Recording software and their dev enviroment
@jsonify It is possible and I thinnk fairly easy to capture the stream seperately and as such without the music
The thing we have to keep in mind about streaming with music is that if it's a video that we want to archive and show again on YouTube, you can't have any music on it due to copyright issues.

@QuincyLarson I'm afraid I'm not entertaining enough to do a stream myself! But If you want I could screen-hero into someone's desktop who wants to stream and let my machine handle running OBS + seperate recording software so we can stream with music, capture a video and not worry about horsepower for the people who normally stream! :p

As a user, I should be able to sign in and have a unique username.
As a user, I should be able to upload an image.
As a user, I should be able to specify a recipient for that image.
As the second user, I should be able to see that an image has been sent to me.
As the second user, I should be able to open the image that someone sent me. This message would only be visible for 10 seconds. Then I would never be able to see it again.
As the second user, I should be able to reply to the image with an image of my own.

That’s just my impression - I don’t have any qualitative evidence to this effect though.

I think the main thing we want to show our viewers is just campers building things. They can read tutorials and watch lectures online. I suspect what they really want to do is peek in on development as it’s happening. I think that’s the magic of twitch - seeing people coding in the wild, watching them make mistakes and solve problems.
@BlueOceanView yes - if this is something you’re interested in doing, and if it will hem closely with our current curriculum (MEAN-stack focus), I think it would be pretty cool!

Oh. Yeah, I don't see why not. We kind of do it already on twitch with the live pair programming but it's not directly teaching little concepts here and there, per se. It's more so learning by doing (or watching others do).
I believe she is suggesting to have a sort of weekly tutoring session to go over basic HTML/CSS functions
@BlueOceanView  I'm not sure I understand the question.

What does everything think about the idea of teaching a lesson in either HTML, CSS or JavaScript as a twitch.tv thing?  For example, spending an hour showing people in more detail how to use CSS selectors and the most common ones used?  Or teach in detail how and when to use an anonymous function. And no, I'm not volunteering. :P  But, since FCC is all about teaching people the basics of web dev, you can show people that through some video training.

It will be a pure utility - letting people know when we stream on Twitch. And labeled transparently as a bot that only does that.

1) I registered 2 new Twitter handles: @twitchcode and @watchcode. I want to integrate one of these with Twitch and basically all it will do is notify followers that we’re live streaming. It’s easier than manually tweeting these out each time we go online.
